questions.question_text: Which of the following command is used to enable logging in iptables?

discussion.content: The answer is C according to the official courseware: Module 3 page 280.

C. $ iptables -A INPUT -j LOG

This command appends a rule to the INPUT chain to log incoming packets. You can further configure the logging options to specify where the log messages should be saved and what information to include in the log entries.
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
modul 03 page 280
answer is C. iptables -A INPUT -} L0G

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
the correct one is C, To enable logging into iptables, we need to add a new rule to the iptables configuration. This can be done using the command: sudo iptables -A INPUT -j LOG
C is correct
C is correct.

questions.question_text: What is the correct sequence of SOC Workflow?

choices.B: Collect, Ingest, Document, Validate, Report, Respond
choices.A: Collect, Ingest, Validate, Document, Report, Respond
choices.C: Collect, Respond, Validate, Ingest, Report, Document
choices.D: Collect, Ingest, Validate, Report, Respond, Document

discussion.content:
The answer is D
CSA courseware Module 1 pg 18

Selected Answer: D
Answer: D. Collect, Ingest, Validate, Report, Respond, Document.
Check page 9 in the book or just google it "SOC workflow".
Collect, Ingest, Validate, Report, Respond, Document
Collect, Ingest, Validate, Report, Respond, Document

questions.question_text:
Wesley is an incident handler in a company named Maddison Tech. One day, he was learning techniques for eradicating the insecure deserialization attacks.
What among the following should Wesley avoid from considering?

choices.B: Understand the security permissions given to serialization and deserialization
choices.D: Validate untrusted input, which is to be serialized to ensure that serialized data contain only trusted classes
choices.A: Deserialization of trusted data must cross a trust boundary

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D

comments.content: Sorry！I make mistake, Answer is C.

discussion.content:
Answer is C according to CSA coursework
Module 6 pg 826

comments.content:
Answer is D: Module 06 pg 826 says:
Avoid serialization for security-sensitive classes. Not allow.
Sorry for my mistake, answer is C

discussion.content: The answer is D
The answer is A. Pag 116

Selected Answer: A
In this attack, an attacker injects malicious code (in this case, a script that displays an alert) into a vulnerable web application

The scenario described in the question demonstrates a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attack. In this attack, an attacker injects malicious code (in this case, a script that displays an alert) into a vulnerable web application, typically by exploiting input validation or output encoding weaknesses.

I believe the correct answer is A. Cross Site Scripting attack. In the example, the attacker is injecting javascript into the URL to create a pop-up warning. In a session attack, the attacker sniffs or otherwise acquires a legit session ID and uses it to gain access to a server, which is not mentioned here. Examples of both are on the OWASP website at the following link.

https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/Session_hijacking_attack

questions.question_text:
An attacker, in an attempt to exploit the vulnerability in the dynamically generated welcome page, inserted code at the end of the company’s URL as follows: http://technosoft.com.com/<script>alert("WARNING: The application has encountered an error");</script>.
Identify the attack demonstrated in the above scenario.
Which of the following formula represents the risk levels?

choices.D: Level of risk = Consequence × Asset Value

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

The formula that represents risk levels in the context of risk management, especially in cybersecurity and general risk assessment, is:

C. Level of risk = Consequence × Likelihood

Correct Answer is C. Level of Risk = Consequence x Likelihood 

pg. 721 Certified SOC Analyst Courseware, Volume 2
